contentrichtext.text: {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Use British English|date=June 2013}} [[File:Andrew Kippis.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Andrew Kippis, 1792 engraving by [[Francesco Bartolozzi]], after [[William Artaud]]]] '''Andrew Kippis''' (28 March 1725 – 8 October 1795) was an [[English Dissenters|English nonconformist]] clergyman and biographer. ==Life== The son of Robert Kippis, a silk-hosier, he was born at [[Nottingham]]. Having gone to school at [[Sleaford]] in [[Lincolnshire]] he passed at the age of sixteen to the [[Dissenting academies|Dissenting academy]] at [[Northampton]], of which Dr [[Philip Doddridge]] was then president. In 1746 Kippis became minister of a church at [[Boston, England|Boston]]; in 1750 he moved to [[Dorking, Surrey]]; and in 1753 he became pastor of a [[Presbyterian]] congregation at [[Westminster]], where he remained till his death. Kippis took a prominent part in the affairs of his church. From 1763 till 1784 he was classical and philological tutor in the [[Coward Trust]]'s academy<ref>''[[Encyclopædia Americana]]'', 1835, article on Kippis</ref> at [[Hoxton]], and subsequently in the [[New College at Hackney]]. In 1778 he was elected a fellow of the [[Society of Antiquaries of London|Antiquarian Society]], and a fellow of the [[Royal Society]] in 1779. ==Works== Kippis was a voluminous writer. He contributed largely to ''[[The Gentleman's Magazine]]'', ''[[Monthly Review (London)|The Monthly Review]]'' and ''The Library''; and he established the ''[[New Annual Register]]''. He published sermons and pamphlets; and he prefixed a life to [[Nathaniel Lardner]]'s ''Works'' (1788). He wrote a life prefixed to Philip Doddridge's ''Exposition of the New Testament'' (1792). His major work is his edition of the ''[[Biographia Britannica]]''; he only lived to publish five volumes (folio, 1778–1793). In this work he had the assistance of [[Joseph Towers]],<ref>Notice by [[Abraham Rees]], ''New Annual Register'' for 1795.</ref> minister of [[Newington Green Unitarian Church]]. One of the works by Kippis is ''Cook's Voyages''. This was first published in London in 1788 <ref>See Hocken, ''Bibliography of New Zealand Literature'', 1909</ref> and includes a letter by Kippis to [[George III of the United Kingdom]] dated 13 June 1788. The book has accounts of the three voyages — [[First voyage of James Cook|1768-1771]], 1772–1775, and 1776-1779 — as well as an account of the character of [[James Cook]], the effects of his voyages, and a commentary on his services. ==See also== * [[Josiah Tucker]] ==References== {{Reflist}} *{{1911}} ==External links== *{{gutenberg author| id=Andrew+Kippis | name=Andrew Kippis}} {{Authority control|VIAF=54179526}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Kippis, Andrew | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 28 March 1725 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 8 October 1795 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kippis, Andrew}} [[Category:1725 births]] [[Category:1795 deaths]] [[Category:People from Nottingham]] [[Category:English Christian ministers]] [[Category:Dissenting academy tutors]] [[Category:18th-century Presbyterian clergy]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society]]
